timeline.body: There is no need for a new copy of the list because `orders` don't change in `IndexSerializer` where it is accessed. Thus I've changed this code to `Collections.unmodifiableList(orders)` to return a reference to `orders` wrapped in unmodifiableList instead of copying all elements to a new list.
timeline.bodyText: There is no need for a new copy of the list because orders don't change in IndexSerializer where it is accessed. timeline.bodyHTML:
I think we should avoid stream API for work intensive place like this, some benchmark https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22658322/java-8-performance-of-streams-vs-collections shows slows performance vs vanilla java

I run benchmark based from SO

@OutputTimeUnit(TimeUnit.NANOSECONDS)
@BenchmarkMode(Mode.AverageTime)
@OperationsPerInvocation(StreamVsVanilla.N)
public class StreamVsVanilla {
    public static final int N = 100000;

    static List<String> sourceList = new ArrayList<>();

    static {
        for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
            sourceList.add("hello");
        }
    }

    @Benchmark
    public Set<String> vanilla() {
        Set<String> adds = new HashSet<>();
        for (final String s : sourceList) {
            adds.add((String) Function.identity().apply(s));
        }
        return adds;
    }

    @Benchmark
    public Set<String> stream() {
        Function<String, String> identity = Function.identity();
        Set<String> adds = sourceList.stream().map(identity).collect(Collectors.toSet());
        return adds;
    }
}

Result is

Benchmark                Mode  Cnt   Score   Error  Units
StreamVsVanilla.stream   avgt   25  10.169 ± 0.576  ns/op
StreamVsVanilla.vanilla  avgt   25   8.789 ± 0.328  ns/op
timeline.author: mad

replies.bodyText: Thanks a lot for checking it! I will change to vanilla version. Let me know if you think we need to change from stream api to vanilla anywhere else also.
replies.author: porunov

replies.bodyText: fixed

timeline.bodyHTML:
The StringBuilder/Iterator pattern appears tree times in this class, with very similar code for each. I suggest replacing this logic and use Java's included String.join. How about something like this:

private static <E> String join(Stream<E> elements, Function<E,String> elementToString, String entrySeparator) {
    Stream<String> convertedElements = elements.map(elementToString);
    return String.join(entrySeparator, (Iterable<String>) convertedElements::iterator);
}

You can then wrap this method for Inputs of type Map<?,?>, Object[] and Collection<?>.
timeline.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText: I don't know how can we use it to join(Map<?, ?> elements, String keyValueSeparator, String entriesSeparator) without redundant concatenations inside elementToString function (i.e.  entry -> entry.getKey() + entriesSeparator + entry.getValue()). So I will use this technique for 2 methods but will leave join(Map<?, ?> elements, String keyValueSeparator, String entriesSeparator) unattached
replies.author: porunov

replies.bodyText: What exactly is redundant in your approach? If you are worried inefficient String concatenation with +, you can do String.join(keyValueSeparator, entry.getKey(), entry.getValue()) in the lambda function.
replies.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText:
String.join(keyValueSeparator, entry.getKey(), entry.getValue()) - is the same as entry.getKey() + keyValueSeparator + entry.getValue() - both approaches create a new concatenated string.
Thus, we are making many unnecessary short-lived new objects in heap.
In the current approach we are not creating unnecessary short-lived objects by putting all string values into the same string buffer which will create a single object after calling toString().
To be clear I am talking about this approach (which isn't sufficient due to unnecessary string concatenation): elements.map(entry -> String.join(keyValueSeparator, entry.getKey(), entry.getValue())).collect(Collectors.joining(separator));. For each entry we are making a new string concatenation instead of making a single concatenation in the end of the loop.
replies.author: porunov

replies.bodyText: resolved

timeline.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText:
From guava documentation newArrayList

Creates a mutable ArrayList instance containing the given elements.

From java docs Arrays.asList

Returns a fixed-size list backed by the specified array

As an array cannot change its size, it can only replace it's elements by other elements but no addition or deletion are supported. So, new ArrayList and Arrays.asList are different lists. If some code will try to remove or add something into that list, we will get UnsupportedOperationException.
replies.author: porunov

replies.bodyText: Good to know! Thank you for pointing that out
replies.author: rngcntr

timeline.author: farodin91

replies.bodyText:
Not sure I correctly understand the question here. I don't see duplication here.
Collections.unmodifiableSet is wrapping some Set into an unmodifiable wrapper. It doesn't add values into a new set. So, there is no way to construct unmodifiableSet if we don't have an underlying set which should be wrapped.
ImmutableSet.of - creates a new set with specified elements. So it is Immutable.
Collections.unmodifiableSet - wraps an existing Set into unmodifiable Set. So, it is Mutable via underlying set but cannot be modified via unmodifiable set. As we are loosing a reference to an underlying set here, it means that this unmodifiable set becomes Immutable, because nobody will be able to change its value, as there is no access to underlying Set anymore.
replies.author: porunov
